DayItem.Title: Questions to the Secretary of State for Justice
Topical Questions to the Secretary of State for Justice
Bathing Waters (Monitoring and Reporting): Ten Minute Rule Motion

BusinessItemDetail.Notes: The Member moving and a Member opposing this Motion may each speak for up to 10 minutes.
BusinessItemDetail.ItemText: That leave be given to bring in a Bill to make provision about monitoring and reporting of water quality in bathing water sites in coastal areas; and for connected purposes.
That the draft Trade Union and Labour Relations (Consolidation) Act 1992 (Amendment of Schedule A2) Order 2024, which was laid before this House on 22 April, be approved.
That the draft Code of Practice on Fair and Transparent Distribution of Tips, which was laid before this House on 22 April, be approved.

BusinessItemDetail.Duration: Until any hour (if the 7.00pm Business of the House motion is agreed to)
BusinessItemDetail.ItemText: That, at this day's sitting, the Speaker shall put the Question necessary to dispose of proceedings on the Motion in the name of the Prime Minister relating to War Graves Week not later than 7.00pm or not later than three hours after their commencement, whichever is the later; proceedings on that Motion may continue, though opposed, after the moment of interruption; and Standing Order No. 41A (Deferred divisions) and provisions of Standing Order No. 9(3) relating to motions that this House has considered a specified matter shall not apply.

That, at this day’s sitting—

(1) Standing Order No. 41A (Deferred divisions) shall not apply to the Motions in the name of Secretary Kemi Badenoch relating to (a) Terms and Conditions of Employment and (b) Employment (Allocation of Tips) and

(2) the Motion in the name of Penny Mordaunt, relating to Business of the House (Today) may be proceeded with, though opposed, until any hour and Standing Order No. 41A (Deferred divisions) shall not apply.

DayItem.Title: GENERAL DEBATE ON WAR GRAVES WEEK

BusinessItemDetail.Duration: Until 7.00pm or for up to three hours, whichever is the later (if the Business of the House (Today) motion is agreed to)
BusinessItemDetail.ItemText: That this House has considered War Graves Week.

BusinessItemDetail.SponsorNotes: on behalf of the Committee of Selection
BusinessItemDetail.ItemText: That Dame Andrea Jenkyns be discharged from the European Scrutiny Committee and Brendan Clarke-Smith be added.

BusinessItemDetail.SponsorNotes: on behalf of the Committee of Selection
BusinessItemDetail.ItemText: That Lee Anderson be discharged from the Home Affairs Committee and Brendan Clarke-Smith be added.

BusinessItemDetail.SponsorNotes: on behalf of the Committee of Selection
BusinessItemDetail.ItemText: That Paul Maynard be discharged from the Justice Committee and Andy Carter and Dehenna Davison be added.

DayItem.Title: Levelling Up, Housing and Communities Committee

BusinessItemDetail.SponsorNotes: on behalf of the Committee of Selection
BusinessItemDetail.ItemText: That Mrs Natalie Elphicke be discharged from the Levelling Up, Housing and Communities Committee and Steve Tuckwell be added.

BusinessItemDetail.SponsorNotes: on behalf of the Committee of Selection
BusinessItemDetail.ItemText: That Damian Collins be added to the Northern Ireland Affairs Committee.

BusinessItemDetail.SponsorNotes: on behalf of the Committee of Selection
BusinessItemDetail.ItemText: That Matt Vickers and Tom Hunt be discharged from the Petitions Committee and Dame Tracey Crouch and Peter Gibson be added.

BusinessItemDetail.Duration: Until 7.30pm or for half an hour (whichever is later)

DayItem.Title: Order of Business
DayItem.Notes: Up to two hours for the first part of the sitting and up to three hours for the second part of the sitting (Standing Order No. 10(1))

DayItem.Title: That this House has considered the impact of smartphones and social media on children

BusinessItemDetail.Notes: The subject for this debate was determined by the Backbench Business Committee.
BusinessItemDetail.RelevantDocuments: e-petition 655473, Ban smartphones and camera phones for under 16s

DayItem.Title: That this House has considered the potential merits of an innovation centre for energy transition in Peterborough

BusinessItemDetail.Notes: The sitting will be suspended from 11.30am to 2.30pm.

DayItem.Title: That this House has considered the prevention of sexual violence in conflict

BusinessItemDetail.RelevantDocuments: Third Report of the International Development Committee of Session 2022–23, From Srebrenica to a safer tomorrow: Preventing future mass atrocities around the world, HC 149, and the Government response, HC 992

DayItem.Title: That this House has considered Royal Bank of Scotland branch closures
That this House has considered the World Species Congress

BusinessItemDetail.Notes:
The debate at 4.30pm will last for up to an hour.

The sitting will be suspended and time added if divisions take place in the main Chamber (Standing Order No. 10(3)).

DayItem.Title: UK COVID-19 Inquiry response costs for Quarter 4 23/24
Second UK Farm to Fork Summit
Equality, Diversity and Inclusion in the Civil Service
Forthcoming End of Day Adjournment Debates

BusinessItemDetail.ItemText: Applications for 30-minute end of day adjournment debates should be made to the Table Office by 7.00pm or rise of the House, whichever is the earlier, on the Wednesdays listed below. Members can submit their application via MemberHub, from their own email account or in hard copy. Application forms are available on the Table Office page on ParliNet. The ballot takes place the day after the deadline. Members who are successful will be contacted by the Speaker’s Office.

DayItem.Title: Tuesday 21 to Thursday 23 May (deadline Wednesday 15 May 7.00pm or the rise of the House, whichever is earlier)
Monday 3 to Monday 10 June (deadline Wednesday 22 May 7.00pm or the rise of the House, whichever is earlier)

BusinessItemDetail.ItemText: The rota for answering Departments is listed below. Applications for 90, 60 and 30-minute debates should be made to the Table Office by 10.00pm or the rise of the House, whichever is the earlier, on the Mondays listed below. Members can submit their application via MemberHub, from their own email account or in hard copy. Application forms are available on the Table Office page on ParliNet. The ballot takes place the day after the deadline. Members who are successful will be contacted by the Speaker's Office.
The ballot for Tuesday 21 and Wednesday 22 May is closed and will take place today.

DayItem.Title: Tuesday 4 and Wednesday 5 June (deadline Monday 20 May 10.00pm or the rise of the House, whichever is earlier)

BusinessItemDetail.ItemText:
The following Departments will answer: 

Attorney General; Business and Trade; Culture, Media and Sport; Defence; Energy Security and Net Zero; Environment, Food and Rural Affairs; Foreign, Commonwealth and Development; Levelling Up, Housing and Communities; Science, Innovation and Technology; Scotland; Treasury

DayItem.Title: Tuesday 11 and Wednesday 12 June (deadline Monday 3 June 10.00pm or the rise of the House, whichever is earlier)

BusinessItemDetail.ItemText:
The following Departments will answer: 

Cabinet Office; Education; Health and Social Care; Home Office; Justice; Northern Ireland; Transport; Wales; Women and Equalities; Work and Pensions
